The code will be something like this:

program codeforces_108b
  implicit none
  integer :: n, i, j, temp
  integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: a

  ! Read input
  read(*, *) n
  allocate(a(n))
  read(*, *) (a(i), i = 1, n)

  ! Sort using bubble sort
  do i = 1, n - 1
      do j = 1, n - i
          if (a(j) > a(j+1)) then
              temp = a(j)
              a(j) = a(j+1)
              a(j+1) = temp
          end if
      end do
  end do

  ! Check consecutive elements do i = 1, n-1
      if (a(i+1) < 2*a(i) .and. a(i) /= a(i+1)) then
          print*, 'YES'
          stop
      end if
  end do

  print*, 'NO'
  deallocate(a)
end program codeforces_108b

for j from 1 to (n - i): Wait, in Fortran, the inner loop would be:

So that the inner loop runs from 1 to (n-i), which for the first iteration (i=1), the inner loop runs up to n-1, comparing all adjacent pairs. program codeforces_108b
  implicit none
  integer :: n, i_sorted, i, j, temp
  integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: a

children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Allocate the array
  allocate(a(n))

  ! Read the array
  read(*,*) (a(i), i=1, n)

  ! Sort using bubble sort
  do i_sorted = 1, n -1
      do j = 1, n - i_sorted
          if (a(j) > a(j+1)) then
              temp = a(j)
              a(j) = a(j+1)
              a(j+1) = temp
          end if
      end do
  end do

  ! Check for required condition
  do i =1, n-1
      if ( a(i+1) < 2 * a(i) .and. a(i) /= a(i+1) ) then
          print*, 'YES'
          stop
      end if
  end do

Alternatively, using selection sort may be better (similar or better time, but perhaps easier?). For selection sort:

do i = 1 to n-1
   min_index = i
   for j = i+1 to n:
      if a(j) < a(min_index), then min_index = j
   swap a(i) and a(min_index)
end do 

Perhaps that's better code? Let me see:

The selection sort code would look like:

do i = 1, n-1
   imin = i
    do j =i+1, n
        if (a(j) < a(imin)) then
            imin = j
        end if
    end do
    ! Swap
    temp = a(i)
    a(i) = a(imin)
    a(imin) = temp
end do

This may be faster than bubble sort for larger arrays, but in any case, for the code submission's purpose, it may be acceptable.

The problem seems to check if there are two consecutive elements in a sorted array where the next element is less than twice the previous one and they are not equal. If such a pair exists, it prints "YES", else "NO".

It sorts the array, then loops through each element except the last, checking if the next element is less than twice the current and they are not equal. If found, returns YES.

1. Reading input: In Fortran, we can use read(*,*) for input. The first input is n. Then, an array of size n needs to be read. But how to dynamically allocate that array? Since Fortran 90 and above supports dynamic arrays. 

2. Sorting the array: Fortran has the sort function. But I need to make sure to sort the array in ascending order. 

3. Looping through the array: Once sorted, loop from i=1 to n-1 (since Fortran arrays are usually 1-based, but in the Java code, it's 0-based; or wait, no, the array index starts at 1 here? Wait, in Fortran, the default is 1-based, unless specified otherwise. So I might need to adjust the indices.)

Wait, let's make sure. Let's see:

Original Java code's loop:

   check a[i+1] < a[i] * 2 etc.

In Java's array, a has indices 0 to n-1. So a.length is n, so a.length -1 is n-1, so i runs from 0 to n-2, which means a[i+1] runs up to a[n-1]. That's correct. 

In Fortran, arrays can be 1-based. Let's define the array to be of size n starting at 1. So the elements are 1 to n. So the loop would be for i=1 to n-1. 

So steps in Fortran:

- Read n from stdin.
- Read the array of n integers.
- Sort the array in ascending order.
- Loop over each element from i=1 to n-1:
   - if a(i+1) < a(i)*2 and a(i) /= a(i+1), then output YES and exit.
- If none found after loop, output NO.

Okay. Now let's structure the Fortran code.

First, declare variables. n as integer, array a as integer array of size n. But in Fortran, arrays need to be declared with known dimensions. Since n is read first, this requires a dynamic allocation.

Pro tip: Use a dynamic array.

So code outline:

program codeforces108b
  implicit none
  integer :: n, i
  integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: a

  ! Read n
  read(*,*) n

  ! Allocate array
  allocate(a(n))

  ! Read array elements
  read(*,*) (a(i), i=1, n)

  ! Sort the array in ascending order
  call sort(a)

  ! Loop through elements
  do i = 1, n-1
     if (a(i+1) < 2*a(i) .and. a(i) /= a(i+1)) then
        print*, 'YES'
        stop
     end if
  end do

  ! If loop completes without stopping, output NO
  print*, 'NO'

  ! Deallocate array (not strictly needed as it's allocated in program scope and exit after)
  deallocate(a)

end program

program codeforces_108b
  implicit none
  integer :: n, i, j, temp
  integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: a

  ! Read input
  read(*, *) n
  allocate(a(n))
  read(*, *) (a(i), i = 1, n)

  ! Sort using bubble sort
  do i = 1, n - 1
      do j = 1, n - i
          if (a(j) > a(j+1)) then
              temp = a(j)
              a(j) = a(j+1)
              a(j+1) = temp
          end if
      end do
  end do

  ! Check consecutive elements
  do i = 1, n-1
      if (a(i+1) < 2*a(i) .and. a(i) /= a(i+1)) then
          print*, 'YES'
          stop
      end if
  end do

  print*, 'NO'
  deallocate(a)
end program codeforces_108b

do i = 1, n-1
   imin = i

        if (a(j) < a(imin)) then
            imin = j
        end if
    end do
    ! Swap
    temp = a(i)
    a(i) = a(imin)
    a(imin) = temp
end do

Wait, this is standard bubble sort. The outer loop runs for n-1 times. Each time, the largest element "bubbles" to the top. The inner loop goes up to n-i.

Wait, but in the inner loop, how to?

Wait, in the inner loop:

for j from 1 to (n - i):

Wait, in Fortran, the inner loop would be:

do j = 1, n - i

    compare a(j) and a(j+1)

    if (a(j) > a(j+1)), swap.

end do

So that the inner loop runs from 1 to (n-i), which for the first iteration (i=1), the inner loop runs up to n-1, comparing all adjacent pairs. Then each subsequent outer loop iteration reduces the uppper limit by 1 because each pass puts the next highest element at the end.

This should work. So the bubble sort is correctly implemented.

Now proceeding with the code. Let me write it again:

program codeforces_108b
  implicit none
  integer :: n, i_sorted, i, j, temp
  integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: a

  ! Read the number of elements
  read(*,*) n

  ! Allocate the array
  allocate(a(n))

  ! Read the array
  read(*,*) (a(i), i=1, n)

  ! Sort using bubble sort
  do i_sorted = 1, n -1
      do j = 1, n - i_sorted
          if (a(j) > a(j+1)) then
              temp = a(j)
              a(j) = a(j+1)
              a(j+1) = temp
          end if
      end do
  end do

  ! Check for required condition
  do i =1, n-1
      if ( a(i+1) < 2 * a(i) .and. a(i) /= a(i+1) ) then
          print*, 'YES'
          stop
      end if
  end do

  ! If nothing found, output NO
  print*, 'NO'

  ! Deallocate the array
  deallocate(a)
end program codeforces_108b
